journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Revisiting the inverse dynamics of the Goughâ€“Stewart platform manipulator with special emphasis on universalâ€“prismaticâ€“spherical leg and internal singularity

article-meta.aff: 2LAMIH FRE CNRS 3304, University of Valenciennes Hainaut-CambrÃ©sis, France

author-notes.corresp: Antoine Dequidt, LAMIH Laboratory, UVHC, Le Mont Houy, F-59313 Valenciennes, France. Email: antoine.dequidt@univ-valenciennes.fr

abstract.p: This article discusses the dynamic modeling for control of Goughâ€“Stewart platform manipulator with special emphasis on universalâ€“prismaticâ€“spherical leg kinematics. Inverse dynamic model of these six degrees of freedom parallel manipulator robots is reviewed, while complete dynamics with true kinematics of universalâ€“prismaticâ€“spherical legs is compared with several models found in the literature. Most existing models have not taken into account some of the legs kinematical effects, namely the legs angular velocity around their axes and the internal singularities due to passive joints; some other used a simplified parameterization to describe the leg kinematics. Furthermore, some kinetic assumption can be used to reduce the computational burden. This article shows the effect of all these simplifications on the driving forces by simulating the different dynamic models for a commercial manipulator and for different sets of geometric and dynamic parameters of manipulator.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Parallel manipulator robots attract significant interest from industry and research because of their mechanical and geometric characteristics (rigidity, speed, precision, etc.). High quality models are necessary for simulating or implementing a model-based control1,2 (computed torque control, feedforward control, trajectory planning, etc.) for a Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator3â€“6 made up of six universalâ€“prismaticâ€“spherical legs (6-UPS), where the P (underlined letter) joints are active, while the U and S joints are passive. Indeed, contrary to the structure of delta-like manipulator (6-RUS, e.g. Hexa) with active revolute joint or hexaglide (6-PUS) for instance, whose actuators are fixed to the basis, those of the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator are fixed to the (mobile) leg. This additional mobile mass greatly modifies the manipulator inertial characteristics, since the UPS legs dynamics must be taken into account. Moreover, the passive joints of legs are generally neglected or simplified in the dynamic modeling, though they can lead to specific singularities7,8 which is referred to internal singularity. Whereas classical kinematic analysis of parallel manipulators use only the relation between the active joint velocities and the platform velocity,9 these specific singularities cannot be identified because they depend on the passive joints.

In this article, we show the importance of considering the true kinematic and kinetic descriptions in order to generate reliable dynamic models for Goughâ€“Stewart manipulators. Moreover, the kinematic assumptions and parameterization have a direct impact on the computational accuracy and efficiency of the dynamic model.

The use of a non-minimal set of parameters (dependent coordinates) constitutes a classical approach in multibody system modeling. It needs the formulation of kinematic constraint equations which altogether with the dynamic equations form a set of differentialâ€“algebraic equations. Some authors like Ait-Ahmed,10 Liu et al.,11 and Miller12 use this type of description for parallel manipulators, which involves the computation of Lagrange multipliers. In the study of Bhattacharya et al.,13,14 we find a method to eliminate the Lagrange multipliers. Another solution is to use an independent set of parameters. The use of spherical coordinates seems to be a natural choice to describe the leg configuration,15â€“20 though it includes approximations. Khalil et al.1,21â€“23 use the modified Denavit and Hartenbergâ€™s parameters as a systematic method to describe the tree structure. Many works are based on a vectorial description.24â€“33 Guo and Li34 derived an explicit compact model with a combination of Newtonâ€“Euler and Lagrange formulations. Screw theory is also used for kinematic and dynamic modeling.35

These varied types of description hide different levels of detail in the kinematic and kinetic descriptions; different assumptions on the dynamic behavior are thus included.
The leg dynamic is neglected.24
Assumptions are made on the legs inertial characteristics (point mass or constant inertia matrix): Geng,15 Lebret et al.,36 and Ji27 consider two punctual masses for each leg; Reboulet et al.25 neglect the upper leg part; and Nguyen16 considers one punctual mass. The leg mass is neglected and a constant diagonal inertia matrix is considered for the whole leg in chapter 9 of Merletâ€™s book.37 The inertial effect of lower and upper parts of the leg is presented in the study of Guo and Li.34 Various levels of kinetic simplifications are also discussed in the study of Wang et al.32
All the leg inertial characteristics are considered, but the rotation around the leg axes is neglected.11,26â€“34,38,39
Another complete dynamic modeling of legs uses the spherical coordinates to describe the kinematics in a simplified way.17,18
To the best of our knowledge only Gallardo et al.,35 Khalil and Guegan,21 Abdellatif and Heimann,40 and Carricato and Gosselin41 proposed a complete rigid dynamic model. Gallardo et al.35 use screw theory but do not explicit the model. In the study of Khalil and Guegan,21 a complete and efficient dynamic model with reduced calculation cost is presented; the frames related to the base are suitably placed in order to minimize the number of geometrical parameters. Abdellatif and Heimann40 proposed an efficient method to derive the inverse dynamic model (IDM) with the use of Lagrangian equations and applied it to the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator. Recently, Carricato and Gosselin41 pointed out common misconceptions related to parameterization and instantaneous kinematic behavior of the leg orientations that may cause positional, kinematic and dynamic miscalculations. The instantaneous kinematic error of the leg orientations has also been shown for the paper of Dasgupta23 in the study of Merlet37 and Tsai.38 Neglecting the instantaneous motion along the leg axes and the asymmetric terms of leg inertial characteristics for the driving force computation yields very well approximated results and decreases the computation burden.41

This article focuses on IDM of the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator with special emphasis on UPS leg kinematic and kinetic assumptions. The paper41 deals with the same issue using a different framework. Our approach focuses on the different kinematic descriptions of the leg and establishes the corresponding Jacobians used in the IDM. Moreover, a phenomenon plays an important role in the IDM, namely the internal singularity depending on the leg passive coordinates, which is deduced from the Jacobian leg written with the true kinematic description. This phenomenon is a reason of the greatest importance to use the true kinematic description of legs instead of simplified descriptions in order to design and control the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator.

In this article, first, IDM is reviewed in section â€˜Kinematics and dynamics of the manipulatorâ€™ as a common framework for the various kinematic leg descriptions. Section â€˜Comparison of leg kinematic descriptionsâ€™ examines the issue of the leg kinematic description with the most popular methods. In section â€˜Comparison of dynamic models with various assumptionsâ€™, results of the IDM based on true leg description are compared to others which contain leg kinetic or kinematic assumptions. The comparison is made for a commercial manipulator and for different sets of geometric and dynamic parameters of manipulator. Conclusions are drawn in the final section.

sec.title: Kinematics and dynamics of the manipulator
sec.p: In order to compare the kinematic descriptions and the dynamic assumptions, a common framework for the modeling is first presented. After a description of the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator (section â€˜Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator descriptionâ€™), derivation of the IDM is achieved through a simple and consistent approach based on the separate dynamic modeling of legs (section â€˜Leg dynamicsâ€™) and mobile platform (section â€˜Mobile platform dynamicsâ€™) and also on the use of the virtual power principle for the whole parallel manipulator (section â€˜IDM of the parallel manipulatorâ€™).

sec.title: Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator description
sec.p:
The Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator (Figure 1) is composed of a fixed base, a mobile platform, and six extensible legs (UPS kinematic chains). A leg is composed of an active prismatic joint (P); each leg i is connected to the fixed base by a universal joint (U), whose center point is denoted as Bi and connected to the mobile platform by a spherical joint (S) with center Pi (Figure 2). Consequently, we can describe the kinematics of each leg i with three coordinate variables (1)qi=[q1iq2iq3i]Tâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6 where q3i denotes the variable of the active prismatic joint. Both passive variables q1i and q2i depend on the leg kinematic description as seen in section â€˜Comparison of leg kinematic descriptionsâ€™. The mobile platform location is controlled by the six active leg joint variables: qa=[q31â€¦q36]T, whose corresponding driving forces are denoted by Î“a= [Î“31â€¦Î“36 ]T. Figure 1.
Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator. Figure 2.
Description of a leg.

A frame {F0} is attached to the fixed base with origin O; a frame {Fp} is attached to the mobile platform with origin P. In order to compute the inverse geometric model of the manipulator, Chasles relationship is used (2)li=p+pi-biâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6withli=BiPi,p=OP,piâ‰¡PPi,biâ‰¡OBi

Position matrix X is composed of vector OP components in the frame {F0}. Rotation matrix between the mobile frame {Fp} and the fixed-base frame {F0} is noted as R(Î¸), so, the relation between the components of a vector fi in frames {F0} and {Fp} is expressed as 0pi=R(Î¸)ppi. The roll, pitch, and yaw angles (Ï†, Î², and Ïˆ, respectively) can be used to express the rotation matrix R(Î¸) with Î¸=(Ï•,Î²,Ïˆ)T, cf. Appendix 1. The six active leg joint variables are defined such as (3)li=q3ieiâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6 where ei is the unit vector of the leg axis. Vector equation (2) is expressed in the frame {F0}, so that the norm of the obtained component matrix 0BiPi leads to the inverse geometric model of the manipulator (4)q3i=â€–X+R(Î¸)ppi-0biâ€–â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6

sec.title: Leg dynamics
sec.p: To derive the dynamic model of the parallel kinematic machine, we first focus on each leg i by cutting the UPS kinematic chain at the S joint (point Pi). Consequently, the dynamic model of each leg can be obtained as a serial manipulator1,42,43 with the external force fi applied by the mobile platform on point Pi (spherical joint center). Velocity vpi of Pi is naturally expressed in terms of leg angular velocity Ï‰i and active joint velocity qÂ·3i, (5)vpi=q3iÏ‰iÃ—ei+qÂ·3iei

In view of the derivation of dynamic model with various kinematic descriptions, vpi is expressed in terms of a velocity matrix Ï‘i. This matrix can contain a set of true velocities Ï‘i=qÂ·i (e.g. the joint velocities) or some quasi-velocities44 Ï‘i=(Ï‰1i,Ï‰2i,qÂ·3i)T depending on the kinematic description of the leg (cf. section â€˜Comparison of leg kinematic descriptionsâ€™) (6)vpi=JiÏ‘iâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6 where Ji is the leg Jacobian. The dynamic model of leg i is then derived via Newtonâ€“Euler or Lagrange formulation of serial kinematic chains,1,42,43 as follows (7)Î“i=Hi(Ï‘Â·i,Ï‘i,qi)-Ji Tfiâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6 where Î“i=[00Î“3i]T for i=1,â€¦,6; Ï‘Â·i is obtained by symbolic derivation of equation (6) in the fixed frame {F0} and Hi(Ï‘Â·i,Ï‘i,qi) is a column matrix containing the leg joint torques and forces due to gravitation and leg acceleration. In order to write the leg dynamic model in Cartesian space, we premultiply (7) with the inverse transpose Jacobian Ji -T. The conditions for existence of the inverse Jacobian of legs are reviewed in section â€˜Comparison of leg kinematic descriptionsâ€™ (8)Ji -TÎ“i=Hxi-fiâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒwithHxi=Ji -THi(Ï‘Â·i,Ï‘i,qi)if|Ji|â‰ 0

sec.title: Mobile platform dynamics
sec.p: The velocity of the spherical joint center Pi can be written in terms of the twist of the platform
ğ•pâ‰¡ (vpÏ‰ ) where Ï‰ is the platform angular velocity (9)vpi=vp-piÃ—Ï‰â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6
Consequently, equation (9) can be rewritten as (10)vpi=[1pâˆ§i T]ğ•pâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6
The dot product of both members in (10) with the vector ei gives the active joint velocities qÂ·3i from (5) (11)qÂ·3i=ei Tvpi=[ei T-ei Tpâˆ§i]ğ•pâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6
Hence, the inverse kinematic model (IKM) of the platform is such as37,38 (12)qÂ·a=Kpğ•pwithKpâ‰¡[e1 T-e1 Tpâˆ§1::e6 T-e6 Tpâˆ§6]

The total wrench of the forces applied on platform is written using Newtonâ€“Euler equation1 (13)ğ”½p=ğ•„Pğ•Â·P+â„P(Ï‰)-ğ”¾P with ğ•„p=[mp1-MSâˆ§MSâˆ§IP], â„p=[Ï‰Ã—(Ï‰Ã—MS)Ï‰Ã—(IPÏ‰)], ğ”¾p=[mp1MSâˆ§]g where g the gravitational acceleration vector 0g=[00-g]T, mp the platform mass, G center of mass, MS its first moment vector such as MSâ‰¡mpPG and MSâˆ§vâ‰¡mpPGÃ—v âˆ€vâˆˆR3, and IP the inertia tensor written with respect to the point P such as IP=IG-MSâˆ§2.

sec.title: IDM of the parallel manipulator
sec.p: An efficient approach to formulate the IDM of the parallel manipulator is to use the virtual powers theorem (extended to dynamics thanks to dâ€™Alembertâ€™s principle), so that the internal forces fi do not appear. Virtual powers of parallel manipulator can be applied to derive the IDM in a concise approach: this formulation uses the projection of leg dynamic models in joint space, namely Hi(Ï‘Â·i,Ï‘i,qi) i=1,â€¦,6, and the total wrench ğ”½p associated to the twist ğ•p of the platform. Consequently, the virtual power P* (the superscript * stands for the virtual quantities) of the manipulator is first written with a dependant virtual velocities field, namely
ğ•p *â‰¡ (vp *Ï‰* )and Ï‘i * for i=1,â€¦,6, so that (14)P*=âˆ‘i=1 6[Ï‘i *TÎ“i-Ï‘i *THi(Ï‘Â·i,Ï‘i,qi)]-ğ•p *Tğ”½p=0

The superscript * stands for the virtual quantities. In the following, virtual powers are rewritten in terms of an independent virtual velocity field. The first term of the sum is reduced to an expression with driving forces Î“a= [Î“31â€¦Î“36 ]T and virtual velocities of the active joints qÂ·a *=[qÂ·31 *â€¦qÂ·36 *]T. Additionally, the use of the platform IKM (12) yields (15)âˆ‘i=1 6Ï‘i *TÎ“i=qÂ·a *TÎ“a=ğ•p *TKp TÎ“a
Using (6) and (10), we obtain (16)Ï‘i *T=ğ•p *T[1pâˆ§i]Ji -T
Combining this equality with the second term of the sum in the virtual power (14) and the leg IDM in Cartesian space (8) yields (17)âˆ‘i=1 6Ï‘i *THi(Ï‘Â·i,Ï‘i,qi)=ğ•p *Tâˆ‘i=1 6[1pâˆ§i]Hxi

Equations (14), (15), and (17) allow the virtual power to be written according to an independent virtual velocity field ğ•p *, which one can arbitrarily choose (18)P*=ğ•p *T(Kp TÎ“a-âˆ‘i=1 6[1pâˆ§i]Hxi-ğ”½p)=0
Consequently, the IDM of the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator can be written in compact form as (19)Kp TÎ“a=ğ”½p+âˆ‘i=1 6ğ”½leg mathvariant="bold">iwithğ”½leg mathvariant="bold">i=[1pâˆ§i]Hxi

The following explicit form of the IDM shows that computation of the driving forces Î“a requires the inversion of the platform IKM Kp as well as the inversion of leg Jacobians Ji. In this regard, the leg kinematic description is an important aspect to consider in order to analyze the dynamics of the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator and to compute the driving forces for a desired platform trajectory (20)Î“a=Kp -T(ğ”½p+âˆ‘i=1 6[1pâˆ§i]Ji -THi(Ï‘Â·i,Ï‘i,qi))

sec.title: Comparison of leg kinematic descriptions
sec.p:
The universal joint of legs is composed of two revolute joints; the following unit vectors define their axis (cf. Figure 4).
u1i is the unit vector of the first axis. It is fixed with respect to the base.
u2i is the unit vector of the second axis. It is perpendicular to u1i and to the leg axis: u2i Tei=0.
Figure 3.
Leg spherical coordinates. Figure 4.
True description of UPS legs.

The orientation of the cross, which is the core component of the universal joint (cf. Figure 4), is defined by both unit vectors u1i and u2i. As an initial step, additional kinematic relationships are written independently of the descriptions. From the velocity vpi (5), two components can be carried out: a component along ei (leg axis), namely qÂ·3i as seen in (11), and a normal vector with respect to ei depending on Ï‰i, (21)ei Tvpi=qÂ·3i (22)eiÃ—vpi=q3i(Ï‰i-(ei TÏ‰i)ei)

Hence, from the foregoing equation, the angular velocity can be decomposed into two components, one normal to the leg axis denoted by Ï‰âŠ¥i and one around the leg axis denoted by Ï‰ei, (23)Ï‰i=Ï‰âŠ¥i+Ï‰eieiwithÏ‰âŠ¥iâ‰¡1q3ieiÃ—vpiandÏ‰eiâ‰¡ei TÏ‰i

In the following, kinematic description of the legs is classified through three methods. The corresponding kinematic models are derived from each formulation in order to analyze the consequences on the leg Jacobians Ji and, in section â€˜Comparison of dynamic models with various assumptionsâ€™, on the dynamics of the manipulator (20).

sec.title: Description neglecting angular velocity around leg axisâ€ƒÏ‰ei
sec.p: The description used in a big number of papers11,25,26,28â€“34,38,39 assumes the leg angular velocity to be normal with respect to the leg axis, i.e. ei TÏ‰i=0. This formulation of the leg angular velocity and its derivative28,29 implied some errors in the final results as pointed in the study of Fu et al.45 and Vakil et al.46

The description uses a mobile vectorial frame attached to the lower part of the leg i, denoted {FâŠ¥i}, and defined by the unit vectors: ei,u2i=u1iÃ—ei/â€–u1iÃ—eiâ€–,eâŠ¥i=eiÃ—u2i. Obviously, the assumption Ï‰eiâ‰¡ei TÏ‰i=0 leads to both particular expressions of angular velocity (24)Ï‰i=1q3ieiÃ—vpi (25)Ï‰i=Ï‰1iu2i+Ï‰2ieâŠ¥i

The forward kinematic relation (5) can be written as (26)vpi=[q3ieâˆ§i Tei](Ï‰iqÂ·3i) and, in vectorial frame {FâŠ¥i} with (25) and matrix of quasi-velocities Ï‘i=(Ï‰1i,Ï‰2i,qÂ·3i)T, as (27)âŠ¥ivpi=âŠ¥iJiÏ‘iwithâŠ¥iJiâ‰¡[0010q3i0-q3i00]
The inverse kinematic relation is derived from (21) and (24) as (28)(Ï‰iqÂ·3i)=[1q3ieâˆ§iei T]vpi and, in vectorial frame {FâŠ¥i} with Ï‘i, as (29)Ï‘i=âŠ¥iKiâŠ¥ivpiwithâŠ¥iKiâ‰¡[00-1/q3i01/q3i0100]

Consequently, we can remark that this kinematic description, which neglects the angular velocity around the leg axis Ï‰ei, leads to leg Jacobian âŠ¥iJi without singularity and âŠ¥iJi -1=âŠ¥iKi if and only if q3i>0,âˆ€i=1,â€¦,6.

sec.title: Use of spherical coordinates
sec.p: The use of spherical coordinates15â€“20 leads to a simple description of leg kinematics with variables qi=[Î¸1iÎ¸2iq3i]T, as indicated in Figure 3. The forward kinematic relation is given in the fixed frame {F0} with the true velocities Ï‘i=qÂ·i (different than the joint velocities) by (30)0vpi=0JiqÂ·iwith0Jiâ‰¡ [-q3iSÎ¸1iSÎ¸2iq3iCÎ¸1iCÎ¸2iCÎ¸1iSÎ¸2iq3iCÎ¸1iSÎ¸2iq3iSÎ¸1iCÎ¸2iSÎ¸1iSÎ¸2i0-q3iSÎ¸2iCÎ¸2i ]and>with {Câ€¢=cos(â€¢)Sâ€¢=sin(â€¢)
This description has an important drawback: kinematics of the universal joint is not taken into account. The angular velocity around the leg axis can easily be computed (31)Ï‰ei=ei TÏ‰i=CÎ¸2iâ€ƒqÂ·3i

As we can see in section â€˜Exact descriptionâ€™, this angular velocity around the leg axis is different than the one obtained with the exact description of the universal joints. Moreover, a mathematical singularity appears in the leg Jacobian matrix for Î¸2i=0 or Ï€, i.e. for a leg in a vertical position (32)|iJi|â‰ 0âˆ€Î¸1i,Î¸2iâ‰ 0,Ï€>andq3i>0
Finally, the use of spherical coordinates is straightforward, though they introduce leg Jacobian singularities without physical meaning in the dynamic model (20).

sec.title: Exact description
sec.p: The leg angular velocity is written in terms of the revolute joint velocities, namely qÂ·1i,qÂ·2i, according to the kinematics described in Figure 421,40,41 (33)Ï‰i=qÂ·1iu1i+qÂ·2iu2i

Given the matrix of leg joint velocities, qÂ·i=[qÂ·1iâ€ƒqÂ·2iâ€ƒqÂ·3i]T, the leg Jacobian Ji can be expressed from the previous equation and equation (5) (34)vpi=JiqÂ·iwithJiâ‰¡[(q3iu1iÃ—ei)(q3iu2iÃ—ei)ei]

From (33), it is apparent that the angular velocity around the ith leg axis, Ï‰ei, due to universal joint is not equal to zero except for the case where the leg axis is perpendicular to the fixed axis of its universal joint (35)Ï‰ei=qÂ·1iei Tu1i

Knowing that the coordinate q2i is the angle between the normal of the cross and the leg axis (cf. Figure 4), the angular velocity Ï‰ei=qÂ·1iSq2i is equal to zero when q2i=0orÏ€. Moreover, the leg Jacobian (34) is singular when the leg axis lies along the fixed axis of the universal joint (36)|Ji|=0â†”u1iÃ—ei=0â†”|q2i|=Ï€2

This internal singularity depending on the leg passive coordinates is named in the following leg passive singularity. In Zlatanovâ€™s singularity-analysis framework,7 this singularity is classified as one of redundant passive motion,8 it is refered as type D-a singular point. Furthermore, the inverse kinematic relation is not defined for all the leg orientations (37)âˆƒKi|qÂ·i=Kivpiâˆ€qÂ·1i,|qÂ·2i|â‰ Ï€2andâ€ƒqÂ·3i>0withKiâ‰¡[1Cq2i 2q3iu1i Teâˆ§i1q3iu2i Teâˆ§iei T]

We can express Ki in a mobile vectorial frame attached to the cross of the leg i. denoted {Fi}. and defined by the unit vectors: u1i, u2i, u3i = u1i Ã— u2i. iKiâ‰¡[0-1Cq2iq3i0Cq2iq3i0Sq2iq3i-Sq2i0Cq2i] with (38)|q2i|â‰ Ï€2andq3i>0

Whereas passive leg singularities have no influence on the IKM (12) of the platform, the driving forces computed with the IDM (20) depend on the closeness of theses singularities; in such a case â€“ |q2i| near Ï€2 â€“ the inversion of the ith leg Jacobian generates big values in the corresponding leg dynamic model in Cartesian space Hxi (cf. (8)), which leads to high driving forces. One attempts to clarify the behavior near a passive singularity. The matrix iKi of the leg inverse kinematic relation shows that the passive singularity only affects the joint velocity qÂ·1i such as (39)qÂ·1i=-1Cq2iq3ivpi.u2i

Thus, if the second joint axis of leg i is not normal to the trajectory of point Pi, i.e. vpi.u2iâ‰ 0, the closeness of a passive singularity of ith leg leads to high value of qÂ·1i and its derivative. To gain in physical insight, one can examine the angular velocity Ï‰i of leg (23). The normal component Ï‰âŠ¥i expressed from (23) in frame {Fi} is not affected by the closeness of the passive singularity, whereas the angular velocity Ï‰ei around the leg axis expressed from (35) and (39) is affected except if the second joint axis of leg i is normal to the trajectory of the point Pi (40)iÏ‰âŠ¥i=(-Cq2ivpi.u2i,Cq2ivpi.u1i+Sq2ivpi.u3i,-Sq2ivpi.u2i)T (41)Ï‰ei=-Sq2iCq2iq3ivpi.u2i
Indeed, the closeness of a passive singularity of ith leg causes high value of Ï‰ei and its derivative (if vpi.u2iâ‰ 0), and consequently, high value of corresponding angular momentum.

sec.title: Comparison of dynamic models with various assumptions
sec.p:
In this section, different IDM methods representing the different leg kinematic descriptions and kinetic assumptions are compared with the help of simulations. The simulation is carried out using the characteristics of a commercial version of the Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator (Figure 5) for which geometric and dynamic parameters are given in Appendix 2. The simulation will be done for two different trajectories in the robot workspace to highlight some phenomena (cf. sections â€˜Vertical motion of point P along Z0 axisâ€™ and â€˜Horizontal motion of point P near leg passive singularitiesâ€™). The fifth-order polynomial time evolution law is used such as the maximum velocity is 1â€‰m/s and maximum acceleration is 2.5â€‰m/s2. Moreover, the models are compared for different sets of geometric and dynamic parameters (cf. section â€˜Comparison for different sets of parameters (geometry and mass)â€™). Figure 5.
Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator, manufactured by MOOG.

The driving forces are computed using the following five methods; the corresponding curves are shown in sections â€˜Vertical motion of point P along Z0 axisâ€™ and â€˜Horizontal motion of point P near leg passive singularitiesâ€™.
Curves FA: Computation with the complete model (cf. Appendix 1).21,40,41
Curves FG: Computation with the model that contains the spherical leg description.17
Curves FD: Computation with the model where the angular velocity around leg axis is neglected.11,26,28â€“34,38,39
Curves FM: Computation with the model where the leg mass is neglected and a constant diagonal inertia matrix Im is considered for the whole leg37 (see the values of Im in Appendix 2).
Curves Fsm: Computation without leg mass and inertia.24

sec.title: Vertical motion of point P along Z0 axis
sec.p:
The mobile platform moves along (vertical) Z0 axis without rotation (cf. Table 1 and Figure 6). For this trajectory, it can be noted that the dynamic behavior of the six legs is identical and this motion involves an evolution of the angular positions q2i far away from the passive singularities of legs (cf. Figure 7). Figure 6.
Vertical motion of P along Z axis. Figure 7.
Joint 2 position for trajectory 1 (i=1,â€¦,6). Table 1.
Trajectory 1: Vertical motion of P along Z axis.
Configuration Initial Final
X [m] 0 0
Y [m] 0 0
Z [m] 0.89 0.45
Roll [radian] 0 0
Pitch [radian] 0 0
Yaw [radian] 0 0

Let us consider the influence of the position of center of gravity for lower leg part (cf. values of xg2, yg2, and zg2 in Appendix 2). By taking xg2â€‰=â€‰0 (actuator supposed to be in the axis of the leg), the three IDM (cf. Figure 8) not neglecting any inertial characteristic (FA, FG, and FD) provide similar results. The two other models (FM, Fsm) are similar. By taking xg2 different from zero to take into account the real position of the actuator, the two IDM containing a kinematic assumption (FG and FD) involve a maximum error from approximately 6% compared to the complete model (FA) for this trajectory (cf. Figure 9). The variation persists at the end of the motion where speeds and accelerations are null because of a miscalculation of the moments of gravitational forces. This is explained by an inaccurate calculation of the actuator position with respect to the leg due to the kinematic assumptions of models FG and FD. Figure 8.
Leg i driving force for different methods for trajectory 1 (i=1,â€¦,6) with xg2â€‰=â€‰0. Figure 9.
Leg i driving force for different methods for trajectory 1 (i=1,â€¦,6) with xg2â€‰=â€‰0.068.

For this trajectory, the models with kinematic assumptions (FG, FD) generate results with similarities with the complete dynamic model (FA). It is different for other trajectories as seen in the followingfor trajectory 1 (i=1,â€¦,6) with xg2â€‰=â€‰0; for trajectory 1 (i=1,â€¦,6) with xg2â€‰=â€‰0.068.

sec.title: Horizontal motion of point P near leg passive singularities
sec.p:
In the same way, the assumptions impacts are exhibited for a horizontal trajectory near leg passive singularities. The mobile platform moves in the plane X0â€“Y0 with a constant orientation (cf. Table 2 and Figure 10). This motion involves an evolution of the angular positions q23 and q26 in the vicinity of the passive singularities of legs 3 and 6 at both the beginning and the end of the motion, respectively (cf. Figure 11). This has a direct impact on angular velocities and accelerations of the first rotational joint of the universal ones (cf. Figures 12 and 13): the velocity and acceleration ranges for the 3rd and 6th legs become very important at the beginning and the end of the motion, respectively. Consequently, all the driving forces computed from the complete IDM (FA) are very different at both the beginning and the end of the motion compared to those computed with the other IDM (cf. Figure 14(a) to (f)). Figure 10.
Horizontal trajectory near leg passive singularities. Figure 11.
Joint 2 position for trajectory 2 (i=1,â€¦,6). Figure 12.
Joint 1 velocity for trajectory 2 (i=1,â€¦,6). Figure 13.
Joint 1 acceleration for trajectory 2 (i=1,â€¦,6). Figure 14.

sec.title: Comparison for different sets of parameters (geometry and mass)
sec.p:
The geometric configuration parameters of the MOOG manipulator (cf. Figure 5) are Rpâ€‰=â€‰0.58â€‰m, Rbâ€‰=â€‰0.79â€‰m, Î²Pâ€‰=â€‰14Â°, and Î²Bâ€‰=â€‰20Â°; and the ratios are RP/RBâ€‰=â€‰0.73, Z/Rbâ€‰=â€‰0.57, and mleg/mPâ€‰=â€‰2.78. Also, the variations of the ratios are applied to IDM by modifying the values of the MOOG parameters, Rp, mP, Î²P, and Î²B, and the height Z of the platform (cf. Table 3). The consequences on driving force can be handled for example on leg 6, as shown in Figure 14(f) and Figures 16 to 23. Figure 16.
Driving force for RP/RBâ€‰=â€‰0.2. Figure 17.
Driving force for RP/RBâ€‰=â€‰0.5. Figure 18.

Driving force for Z/RBâ€‰=â€‰1. Figure 20.
Driving force for Î²Pâ€‰=â€‰28Â°, Î²Bâ€‰=â€‰20Â°. Figure 21.
Driving force for Î²Pâ€‰=â€‰28Â°, Î²Bâ€‰=â€‰40Â°. Figure 22.

cf. fig. 22 cf. fig. 23 cf. fig. 14f

For a ratio RP/RB between 0.2 and 1, cf. Figures 14(f), 16, and 17 (RP/RBâ€‰=â€‰0.73), the dynamics is strongly affected by the kinematic assumption, whereas for a ratio under 0.2 the difference between the three IDM not neglecting any inertial characteristic (FA, FG, and FD) is less important and the kinetic assumption is still significant. Furthermore, the larger the ratio Z/RB, the less the kinematic assumption influence, as seen in Figure 14(f) (Z/RBâ€‰=â€‰0.57) and Figures 18 and 19. The influence of kinematic assumption also occurs for various distributions of joints on platform and base, cf. Figures 14(f), 20, and 21, while the spherical leg description can lead to great miscalculation for some distributions of joints such as Î²Pâ€‰=â€‰28Â°, Î²Bâ€‰=â€‰40Â°, cf. Figure 21. Finally, as expected, the ratio mleg/mP can be viewed as a gain factor of the impact of kinematic and kinetic assumptions, cf. Figures 14(f), 22, and 23 (mleg/mPâ€‰=â€‰2.78).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article outlined the dynamics of Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator and focused on leg modeling considerations. The most popular descriptions of the leg kinematics have been reviewed. It was shown that modeling of the UPS leg kinematics with assumptions or simplifications can lead to important mistakes in the dynamic description of the parallel manipulator. The angular velocity of legs around their axes can be taken into account only if a true description of universal (passive) joints is used. Moreover, the leg Jacobians which link the passive and active joint velocities with the platform velocity contain passive leg singularities. The closeness of one of these singularities implies effects on the driving forces computed with IDM via the inversion of leg Jacobians.

With the dynamic modeling method overviewed in the first section, several models have been developed in order to examine with simulations the effects of both kinematic and kinetic assumptions. In the case of the commercial robot employed for simulation, computation of the driving forces presents big errors if the complete IDM is not used. For these numerical values, comparison between the different IDM shows that the kinematic assumptions are more important than the kinetic ones. A variation of geometric and dynamic parameters leads to extend the results for different manipulator configurations.

Several open questions remain. The passive joints or the related linkages are very often simplified for analysis of parallel manipulators; what is the influence of the passive joints kinematics on dynamics for some kinematic structures? When passive singularities occur in the neighborhood of machine workspace, what is a good compromise between reliability and computational burden for generation of models dedicated to online trajectory planning and model-based control? Model-based control including true kinematics of passive joints requires geometric calibration: which method can be defined since passive joints have no sensors in most cases?

sec.title: Manipulator description
sec.p:
In order to present an explicit form of the complete IDM, the following notations are used.
{Fi}: Local frame of leg i attached to the fixed base with origin Bi at the center of the universal joints; the axis Xi of the frame {Fi} is along the first rotation axis of the joint U. The transformation from {F0} to {Fi} is composed of the translation to the point Bi and two rotations (angle Î³i around axis Z0, Î±i around new Yi axis), cf. Figure 24.
{F2i}, {F3i}: Local frames of leg i attached to the lower and the upper parts with origins Bi and Pi, respectively. Axes for both frames are X2i, the second rotation axis of the universal joint Y2i and the leg axis Z2i (cf. Figure 25). These frames are used to define the inertia matrix (cf. Appendix 2).
The components of u1i, u2i, and ei in frames {Fi} are expressed as
(42)iu1i=(100)iu2i=(0Cq1iSq1i)iei=(Sq2i-Sq1iCq2iCq1iCq2i)with {Câ€¢=cos(â€¢)Sâ€¢=sin(â€¢)
The rotation matrix between the mobile frame {Fp} and the fixed base frame{F0} is noted as 0Rp=R(Î¸), so that the relation between the components of a vector fi in frames F0 and Fp is expressed as 0pi=0Rpppi. The rotation matrix R(Î¸) is given by the following formula according to the roll, pitch, and yaw angles (Ï†, Î², and Ïˆ, respectively): R(Î¸)=rot(z,Ï•).rot(y,Î²).rot(x,Ïˆ)
(43)R(Î¸)=[CÏ•CÎ²CÏ•SÎ²SÏˆ-SÏ•CÏˆCÏ•SÎ²CÏˆ+SÏ•SÏˆSÏ•CÎ²SÏ•SÎ²SÏˆ+CÏ•CÏˆSÏ•SÎ²CÏˆ-CÏ•SÏˆ-SÎ²CÎ²SÏˆCÎ²CÏˆ] Figure 24.

iR0: Rotation matrix which describes the orientation of frame {F0} in the leg frame {Fi}; based on the previous definition of the frame {Fi}, the rotation matrix is 0Ri are given by rot(z,Î³).rot(y,Î±)
(45)iR0=[CÎ³iCÎ±iSÎ³iCÎ±i-SÎ±i-SÎ³iCÎ³i0CÎ³iSÎ±iSÎ³iSÎ±iCÎ±i] such as iBiPi=iR00BiPi

sec.title: Inverse geometric model of legs
sec.p: To compute IDM of the legs Hi(qÂ·Â·,qÂ·i,qi) the passive coordinates q1i,q2i are needed. To this end, the leg direct geometric model associated to one leg i is expressed as a relation between the joint coordinates and the components iBiPi= (iXi,iYi,iZi)T of the vector BiPi in frame {Fi} (46)(iXiiYiiZi)=[Sq2iq3i-Sq1iCq2iq3iCq1iCq2iq3i]â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒforâ€ƒi=1,â€¦,6

sec.title: IDM algorithm
sec.p: To compute the IDM of Goughâ€“Stewart manipulator, we need first the geometrical parameters: ppi, 0bi, iR0,0u1i, 0u2i, for i=1,â€¦,6. Then, the platform trajectory planning provides in frame {F0} the inputs of the model: X, Î¸, 0ğ•p, 0ğ•Â·p. Finally, the IDM can be computed as follows
